newsitem.title: UK: London gold moves sideways, platinum crumbles.
newsitem.headline: London gold moves sideways, platinum crumbles.

text.p: Gold and silver moved uneasily in tight price bands on Friday, searching for market direction after coming off a steady price surge earlier this week.
But platinum tumbled to recent lows on New York-led technical selling, dropping briefly below the price of gold for the first time in nearly three years.

Bullion fixed at $382.55 an ounce, up slightly from the morning's fix of $382.20 but nowhere near the week's highs around $384 an ounce. Although gold was finding some support around $382 an ounce, it appeared to lack the momentum to carry it higher.
"Gold's bursts of strength is running out of steam, as is that of platinum," technical analyst Elli Gifford of Investment Research of Cambridge said in a commentary.
The market registered no reaction to a rebound in U.S. durable goods orders in September after a sharp drop in August. It also sparked minimal response in U.S. stocks.
But the South African rand was at an all-time low after plunging below 4.60 to the dollar on Friday, which was seen possibly encouraging selling by gold producers.
Gold, with the rest of the precious metals in tow, had notched up about $4.00 at the start of the week in an apparent recovery from a downtrend since early September.
But a tumble in silver prices on Thursday afternoon dragged gold and the other precious metals lower.
Silver was indicated unchanged from Thursday's London close at $4.90/$4.92 an ounce.
Platinum, which had drifted lower with gold on Thursday and slumped further overnight, took another hit shortly after its afternoon fixing of $384.25 an ounce.
Prices crumbled to recent lows near $380 an ounce, then quickly rebounded slightly higher.
"The price was pushed down and some stops on NYMEX (New York's futures market) were hit. This is a technical move, because there's a dearth of fundamental news," a dealer said.
"It's getting some support technically and because it's flat with gold," he added.
Platinum was indicated at $382.50/$383.50 an ounce, down $3.10 an ounce from Thursday's London close, after hitting a high of $388.50 an ounce earlier in the week.
Its sister metal palladium was slightly easier at $116.25/$117.25, down $1.00 from Thursday's close.
